We also take action by painting and placing rocks in our communities as a form of protest and to educate our neighbors, because our students and community have vibrant, powerful voices that can affect change. #LCWearsOrange #WearOrange #GunViolenceAwareness #DisarmHate #ProtectKidsNotGuns

shared_text:
Sarah Friedman
May 5 at 11:43 AM ·

We received a few donations to the Learning Community family emergency fund today of $1200 from families of the school donating their stimulus checks to support families in our community who don’t get the stimulus money but need it and deserve it.

Federal government dollars excluding any low wage workers from basic and necessary resources in a time of such great suffering is an act of inhumanity with lasting, possibly irreparable damage to our society. Valuing some lives more than others is not a wound easily healed.

These gifts from LC families to other LC families is a true act of love, and gives me hope that in our community, city and state we can care for each other as equally valued human beings.

So grateful.

Second Round of Targeted Aerial Mosquito Spraying Now Scheduled for Wednesday, Weather Permitting.

The second round of aerial mosquito treatments will likely begin on the night of Wednesday, September 25, depending on weather conditions, the Department of Environmental Management (DEM) and the Rhode Island Department of Health (RIDOH) announced today. With favorable weather, the two planes conducting the operation should be able to treat the two spraying zones simultaneously and finish on Wednesday.

Two mosquito detections of EEE have occurred in Central Falls and two have occurred in Westerly. A horse was also diagnosed with EEE in Westerly. In addition, several EEE cases and positive mosquitoes have been detected in Connecticut and Massachusetts, some in areas that border Rhode Island. Generally, spraying in Rhode Island is occurring in four-mile radiuses around positive samples and cases.

Sarah Friedman represents The Learning Community at Harvard tonight, 7/24/2019

LC co-founder and co-director Sarah Friedman is leading two sessions today at the Harvard Graduate School of Education Conference Family Engagement in Education: Creating Effective Home and School Partnerships for Student Success Institute.

Sarah’s sessions are focused on the revolutionary power of family engagement to challenge systems of oppression, racism, sexism and classism, in public education, and are based on what she has learned alongside the families of the LC. LC families come from over 40 different countries, speak multiple languages, face the tremendous challenges of poverty, and have consistently demonstrated among the highest levels of family engagement of a pool of 6,000 schools regionally over 15 years.
